awd_titl_txt: Experimental Model Systems for Intracellular Compartmentalization: Dynamic Formation/Disassembly of Model Organelles in Artificial Cells
awd_abstract_narration:
Technical Description:   This proposal is based on the idea that it may be possible to realize key structural and functional aspects of subcellular organization due to the physicochemical phenomena that arise in solutions that are crowded with macromolecules "like the cytoplasm and nucleoplasm are" even in the absence of specific biomolecular interactions.  Of particular interest is aqueous phase separation, which commonly occurs in polymer solutions and offers a means of compartmentalization. This work will evaluate two hypotheses: (1) that phase separation in the crowded intracellular environment could be largely responsible for the existence and properties of non-membranous organelles, and (2) that these structures could in turn serve as templates for membrane assembly. Experimental models of subcellular cytoplasmic and nuclear compartments will be developed based on crowded solutions of RNA, polyamines, proteins, and neutral polymers. Protein phosphorylation will be used to drive formation and disassembly of microcompartments that will serve as model organelles. Three research objectives are proposed: (1) Dynamic assembly/disassembly of model non-membranous organelles based on aqueous phase compartments that form in response to protein phosphorylation state. (2) Templated membrane formation around these model organelles.  (3) Primitive model for mitosis/cell cycle in cell-sized lipid vesicles that contain the crowded solution and phase compartment-based model organelles. 

Nontechnical Description: Intracellular organization is a hallmark of living cells, with both membrane-bounded (e.g., nucleus) and non-membranous organelles (e.g., nucleolus, P-granules) performing key cellular functions. The central questions driving these investigations are: What role do relatively nonspecific chemical and physical effects play in subcellular organization and the associated functions of biological cells, and how does complexity arise from a small number of simple molecular components?  The investigators hypothesize that, despite the deliberate simplicity of the proposed model cells, they will be able to mimic complex biological processes and specific biochemical interactions, such as the reversible formation and dissolution of RNA and protein-rich compartments, the formation of interior membranes around pre-existing protein-rich compartments, and finally to model cell division in a very primitive mimic of the mitotic cell. 

Broader Impacts. Two graduate students will be trained at the interface of molecular and cell biology, chemistry, biophysics and materials science.  Undergraduate students will be recruited to work on this project during the academic year for course credit and in the summer through the various on-site REU programs, with a target of one student during the academic year and one or two students during the summer. Support for one K-12 teacher each summer is included in the budget.  The investigators will team with the existing Research Experiences for Teachers program in the PSU MRSEC. Teachers will perform experiments and develop curriculum materials to bring back to their own classrooms the following school year. Real-world examples go beyond the intracellular organelles that motivate the intellectual merit of this proposal to also include, e.g., food science, drug delivery, and environmental remediation.

This award is being funded by the Systems and Synthetic Biology Cluster in MCB/BIO and co-funded by the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in CHE/MPS.

por.por_cntn:
Outcomes from this project broadly relate to generating better experimental model systems for biological cells, and using those models to evaluate how basic physical chemical principles could underlie seemingly complex biological processes. In particular we sought to capture the crowded, compartmentalized, and dynamic nature of the cellular interior. To do this, we used solutions of macromolecules capable of undergoing liquid-liquid phase separation to form two or more coexisting aqueous phases, between which other molecules could partition. This physicochemical mechanism is thought to be how membraneless organelles in the cytoplasm and nucleoplasm of living cells form. We focused on RNA-rich droplet phases, and developed routes to reversibly form and dissociate them via temperature or enzymatic activity. This provided a means to sequester and release biomolecules, potentially serving as a way to control biochemical reactions. We found that strong media effects can be present when reactions are performed in phase-separated media; these can enhance or inhibit reaction rates and must be taken into account when designing multiphase biochemical reaction models. We also looked at the interaction of RNA-rich droplet phases with lipid vesicles, which serve as a simplified biological membrane. We found that lipid vesicles could be assembled around RNA-rich droplet phases without disrupting solute access to the droplet interior via diffusion. We also identified approaches to encapsulate coexisting phases within water-in-oil droplets and cell-sized (“giant”) liposomes, to form models for compartmentalized biological cells.

 

A particularly significant result of this project was our demonstration that peptide phosphorylation state could be used to control the assembly and dissociation of peptide/RNA-rich droplets. Post-translational modifications such as phosphorylation are thought to play important regulatory roles in forming and dissociating similar protein/RNA-rich membraneless organelles in vivo, but the mechanisms by which these modifications control organelle formation are not well understood. Our peptide/RNA-rich droplets were produced by a type of liquid-liquid phase separation called complex coacervation that relies on ion pairing interactions between polyelectrolytes of opposite charge. We used a short peptide sequence that contained four positively-charged arginine residues to provide multivalent ion pairing interactions with a long, flexible polyuridylic acid RNA strand, and two serine residues as phosphorylation sites. This peptide could be converted between zero and +4 net charge by enzymatic phosphorylation/ dephosphorylation. When the peptide was in its fully-dephosphorylated state, it was able to undergo coacervation with RNA, which is anionic. Upon phosphorylation, this ion pairing was disrupted and the system returned to a well-mixed single phase. These results showed that the change in net charge on a peptide due to its phosphorylation state was sufficient to control phase separation; no conformational change, relocalization, or disruption of specific binding interactions was required. Although more elaborate systems for controlling phase separation likely exist in vivo, the fact that such a simple mechanism can be effective suggests both a possible evolutionary path from simpler to more complex mechanisms and a means of achieving this important level of control over solute sequestration and release in nonliving systems, e.g. for potential biotechnological applications.

 

The findings of the research performed for this project are important in the fields of physical chemistry and cell biology. New insight into properties and possible biological roles of membraneless organelles was uncovered and disseminated in the form of presentations and peer-reviewed publications. Experimental systems developed here have already been adopted by other researchers; these include the spermine/RNA system and the phosphoregulation concepts. This project also provided educational and professional development opportunities for graduate students, undergraduate students, and K-12 teachers who participated. Two graduate students wrote and defended doctoral theses based on their research for this project. Three additional doctoral students are progressing towards their degrees. Graduate students authored peer-reviewed publications and presented their research results at a variety of local and national meetings. An undergraduate student who worked on this project presented his work at the National Meeting of the American Chemical Society and was a co-author on a peer-reviewed publication. Several teams of K-12 teachers developed hands-on, inquiry experiments and lesson plans based on surface and emulsion science related to the scientific goals of this project. The teachers spent six weeks working in the laboratory to develop these materials with assistance from the graduate students and the Principal Investigator. They presented their work at the end of the summer and then brought the activities and lessons back to their home classrooms for implementation. Teachers, graduate students and the Principal Investigator remained in contact after these summer experiences, and in several cases graduate students visited the teachers’ classrooms to present science outreach activities and/or career information. Graduate students were also involved in a variety of other educational and outreach activities.
